August 1921.SECEET.c p.-3263.cabinet.WEEKLY SURVEY OF THE STATE OF IRELAND.Memorandum by the Chief Secretary for Ireland.I SUBMIT for the consideration of the Cabinet my survey for the week ended the 22nd instant.General State of the Country.Observance of Truce Conditions.There has been no change in the general state of the country since my last report. The truce arrangements continue to work without violence, but I know that Sinn Fein Volunteers are openly drilling in many parts of the country, and that there has been an increase in the activity of Sinn Fein Courts. Representations in regard to both these matters have been made to the Chief Sinn Fein Liaison Officer, who declines to accept the view that a violation of the terms of the truce is involved in either case. There is undoubtedly some force in his contention that by collecting their men for the purpose of drilling the local Sinn Fein leaders are able to keep them under supervision and proper control.A matter of more practical importance is the alleged requisitioning of money for the maintenance of the Irish Republican Army. Activities of this kind undoubtedly constitute a very serious violation of the truce, but the Sinn Fein Liaison Officer has stated explicitly that if such requisitions have been made they are quite unauthorised, and he has promised that the matter will be taken up immediately by the heads of the organisation.Disturbances in Belfast.The dangerous state of party feeling in Belfast is evidenced by a number of sporadic acts of violence committed without apparent provocation and having no assignable motive other than sectarian animosity. a serious outrage of this character was perpetrated on the night of Sunday, the 21st instant, when a bomb was thrown in Tyrone. Street (a Catholic quarter), damaging 9 houses and injuring 6 persons, one of whom, a girl of 20, was removed to hospital in a dangerous condition. On the following night an attack was made with bombs and rifle and revolver fire upon the Catholic quarter of North Queen Street, and considerable damage to property was committed. The disturbance was quelled by the Police about 11-30 p.m., and no further outbreak has since occurred.Trials of Civilians by Court-Martial.Twenty-seven trials of civilians by court-martial were concluded during the week, resulting in 16 convictions and 11 acquittals. The following is an analysis of the sentences imposed : 12 sentences of penal servitude (3 years to 15 years). . 2 sentences of imprisonment with hard labour (1 year). 2 -fines (51.)Total 16Eight of the convictions were for the possession of arms and ammunition and severe sentences of penal servitude were imposed (15 years in 2 cases, 10 years in 3 cases, 5 years in 2 cases, and 3 years in 1 case). The acquittals included the case of a Head Constable of the Royal Irish Constabulary who was charged with manslaughter, and the case of a Constable charged with assault. Another Constable charged with assault was convicted and sentenced to a fine of 51. or 2 months' imprisonment in lieu, but con-firmation of the sentence was withheld by the Confirming Officer.Internment Orders.The following statement shows the position as regards internments up to the Present Political Situation in Ireland.According to official Sinn Fein announcements, the terms of Mr. de Valera's next reply to the Prime Minister have now been considered by Dail Eireann in secret session, and the reply is expected to be delivered in London this week. The secret of its contents has been well kept from the public, and the Irish press has indulged in little speculation on the subject. As to one thing, however, there appears to be no room for doubt, and that is the almost universal desire on the part of the people of Southern Ireland for an immediate peace. Reports from all sources indicate that the public confidence that negotiations must end in a settlement is as strong as ever, and despite the tone of Mr. de Valera's recent speeches, the possibility that the Sinn Fein leaders will take any action intended or calculated to bring about a retfurn of the conditions which prevailed before the truce appears nowhere to be seriously contemplated by the public.H.
